review_title: Warm and welcoming culture in a historic building
pros: Small private school with openminded faculty and staff Small intimate classes Great location Unique building interior
cons: Small campus compared to other schools in the Boston area

pros: Very flexible hours, recomended if you are an athlete

job_title: Public Safety Officer in Boston, MA
pros: Friendly staff, beautiful campus, ease of access
cons: Haunted buildings, lack of ability to act from the administration, lack of respect from the students

pros: People are nice and the team I worked with were phenomenal. Very underutilized. Schedule was good. Great place to learn the ropes of higher Ed.
cons: Higher up’s are out of touch with the needs of company and students. They do not like change. Departments are very understaffed and they expect more numbers without providing proper resources.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Boston, MA
pros: In my time at Fisher, I learned everything you need to know from an admissions standpoint. From the application, to the student moving in, I was involved with every aspect of it. I cannot thank Fisher enough for giving me all the knowledge to take my career to the next level.
cons: For me, I didnt have many cons. But thats my experience.

job_title: Financial Aid Counselor in Boston, MA
pros: Fair to work for, however, it depended on your manager and if they could protect you from campus politics.

review_title: Entry level job for someone joining law enforcement
job_title: Public Safety Officer in Boston, MA
pros: Co-workers were super friendly, supportive and helpful.
cons: The leadership for the Department was weak and in-experienced. Students had no respect for public safety staff trying to do their job and only liked you if you let them get away with everything. You worked alone on the overnight shift with two contract security guards who had no interest in being there while having to patrol alleyways unarmed right in the heart of Boston.

pros:
Good benefits
Collaborative environment 
It is always nice helping college students through their admissions processes
cons: The industry is a very challenging environment. Many colleges are shrinking, merging with other colleges, or shutting down due to low enrollment rates

job_title: Financial Aid Counselor in Boston, MA
pros: You work with a dedicated team to help students manage their accounts.
cons: There was a lot of turnover.

review_title: The worst college I've taught at.
pros: If you are a student who couldn't get into college because you shouldn't have graduated from high school but did then this is the type of college for you.
cons: Exploits students, mostly younger, that shouldn't be in college.  These students cheat because they got away with it in high school and Fisher College faculty allow it.  All they care about is passing the students so they can get money.  This a terrible for profit school and the word is out with businesses.  Most of the students are there because they want the degree and don't care if they learn anything.  So they or their parents are burdened with this cost.  I was laughed at by my department head and some other so-called professors there when I tried to explain that my students didn't have the skills to pass my class because they were passed from the other classes without understanding the material.  From speaking with other instructors this is true no matter what the subject is.  The students are disrespectful by acting ghetto and the faculty exploits them by taking their money and sticking some of them with loans that they won't be able to pay back for a long time, if ever.

review_title: Disappointing, school will not succeed without changes
pros: Easy location to get to. Teach anything you want, no one is really paying attention.
cons: This was a very disappointing experience. First, the pay is horrible, but money is not why I wanted to teach at Fisher. I actually believed they wanted to expand the school and create innovative programs, but this turned out to a wish with no roadmap. The executive staff seem unaware of the problems on the ground. Program directors have no resources whatsoever and no way to support adjuncts in their jobs. School does not seem to care much about students welfare, the administrative staff was ready to expel anyone regardless of their situation. There were students with seriously bad home situations I tried to help along, but the school would continue to insist I flunk them. This is really too bad, because I actually enjoyed working with students and seeing them succeed when some other professors expressed open hatred for their classes. School constantly asks for extra work from adjuncts with little reward. When I left there was no exit interview, no thank you for your service, not even an acknowledgement. Made the right choice in moving on.

review_title: Great place to be an Adjunct
job_title: Adjunct Professor in Woodstock Valley, CT
pros: Autonomy. No micromanagement.  Educational Freedom. Great management and adjunct community.  I now teach the same three curses year round which makes management and organization easier.  Classes always run.
cons: I really can't think of any.  I have had nothing but a positive experience working for Fisher.  I would hope to continue working as an online adjunct for years to come.  I just wish I could teach more classes.  Caps at 9 credits per two semesters max.

review_title: Small school, but lots of opportunities
pros: People are open and friendly-- it's more of a family atmosphere than anything else. There are many staff members who have been at the school for more than a decade, which speaks to its attrition rate.
cons: Although there are many opportunities to learn on the job, there are still limits to growth. Small offices often mean your supervisor has to leave the college before you're able to be promoted to a higher position.

review_title: Personal Service in a College Setting
pros: As an adjunct professor, you are given great atonomy to teach your course  the way  you see fit.
cons: Since it is such a small college, we don't get the variety of students who stick out the four years.

pros: Great co-workers who help you in any way possible. Good stepping stone for something more substantial later on.
